member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.CHANGEFILTERSTRUCT
member.summary: Contains extended result information obtained by calling the ChangeWindowMessageFilterEx function.

remarks.para: Certain messages whose value is smaller than WM_USER are required to pass through the filter, regardless of the filter setting. There will be no effect when you attempt to use this function to allow or block such messages.

An application may use the ChangeWindowMessageFilter function to allow or block a message in a process-wide manner. If the message is allowed by either the process message filter or the window message filter, it will be delivered to the window.
The following table lists the possible values returned in ExtStatus.
This doc was truncated.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

summary.para: Type: DWORDThe size of the structure, in bytes. Must be set to sizeof(CHANGEFILTERSTRUCT), otherwise the function fails with ERROR_INVALID_PARAMETER.
Type: DWORDIf the function succeeds, this field contains one of the following values.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ChildWindowFromPointExFlags.CWP_SKIPTRANSPARENT

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_BYTEALIGNCLIENT
member.summary: Aligns the window's client area on a byte boundary (in the x direction). This style affects the width of the window and its horizontal placement on the display.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_BYTEALIGNWINDOW
member.summary: Aligns the window on a byte boundary (in the x direction). This style affects the width of the window and its horizontal placement on the display.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_CLASSDC
member.summary: Allocates one device context to be shared by all windows in the class. Because window classes are process specific, it is possible for multiple threads of an application to create a window of the same class. It is also possible for the threads to attempt to use the device context simultaneously. When this happens, the system allows only one thread to successfully finish its drawing operation.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_DBLCLKS
member.summary: Sends a double-click message to the window procedure when the user double-clicks the mouse while the cursor is within a window belonging to the class.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_DROPSHADOW
member.summary: Enables the drop shadow effect on a window. The effect is turned on and off through SPI_SETDROPSHADOW. Typically, this is enabled for small, short-lived windows such as menus to emphasize their Z order relationship to other windows.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_GLOBALCLASS
member.summary: Indicates that the window class is an application global class.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_HREDRAW
member.summary: Redraws the entire window if a movement or size adjustment changes the width of the client area.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_NOCLOSE
member.summary: Disables Close on the window menu.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_OWNDC
member.summary: Allocates a unique device context for each window in the class.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_PARENTDC
member.summary: Sets the clipping rectangle of the child window to that of the parent window so that the child can draw on the parent. A window with the CS_PARENTDC style bit receives a regular device context from the system's cache of device contexts. It does not give the child the parent's device context or device context settings. Specifying CS_PARENTDC enhances an application's performance.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_SAVEBITS
member.summary: Saves, as a bitmap, the portion of the screen image obscured by a window of this class. When the window is removed, the system uses the saved bitmap to restore the screen image, including other windows that were obscured. Therefore, the system does not send WM_PAINT messages to windows that were obscured if the memory used by the bitmap has not been discarded and if other screen actions have not invalidated the stored image. This style is useful for small windows (for example, menus or dialog boxes) that are displayed briefly and then removed before other screen activity takes place. This style increases the time required to display the window, because the system must first allocate memory to store the bitmap.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ClassStyles.CS_VREDRAW
member.summary: Redraws the entire window if a movement or size adjustment changes the height of the client area.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DeviceContextValues.DCX_NORESETATTRS
member.summary: Does not reset the attributes of this DC to the default attributes when this DC is released.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DeviceContextValues.DCX_CLIPCHILDREN
member.summary: Excludes the visible regions of all child windows below the window identified by hWnd.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DeviceContextValues.DCX_CLIPSIBLINGS

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DeviceContextValues.DCX_PARENTCLIP
member.summary: Uses the visible region of the parent window. The parent's WS_CLIPCHILDREN and CS_PARENTDC style bits are ignored. The origin is set to the upper-left corner of the window identified by hWnd.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DeviceContextValues.DCX_EXCLUDERGN
member.summary: The clipping region identified by hrgnClip is excluded from the visible region of the returned DC.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DeviceContextValues.DCX_INTERSECTRGN
member.summary: The clipping region identified by hrgnClip is intersected with the visible region of the returned DC.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DeviceContextValues.DCX_EXCLUDEUPDATE

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DeviceContextValues.DCX_INTERSECTUPDATE

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DeviceContextValues.DCX_LOCKWINDOWUPDATE
member.summary: Allows drawing even if there is a LockWindowUpdate call in effect that would otherwise exclude this window. Used for drawing during tracking.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DeviceContextValues.DCX_USESTYLE

member.remarks: Internal; do not use

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DeviceContextValues.DCX_VALIDATE
member.summary: When specified with , causes the DC to be completely validated. Using this function with both and is identical to using the function.
member.remarks: Reserved; do not use (it is documented on Windows CE GetDCEx function on MSDN).

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.DIALOG_CONTROL_DPI_CHANGE_BEHAVIORS
member.summary: Describes per-monitor DPI scaling behavior overrides for child windows within dialogs. The values in this enumeration are bitfields and can be combined.
member.remarks:
This enum is used with SetDialogControlDpiChangeBehavior in order to override the default per-monitor DPI scaling behavior for a child window within a dialog.
These settings only apply to individual controls within dialogs. The dialog-wide per-monitor DPI scaling behavior of a dialog is controlled by .

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DIALOG_CONTROL_DPI_CHANGE_BEHAVIORS.DCDC_DEFAULT
member.summary: The default behavior of the dialog manager. The dialog managed will update the font, size, and position of the child window on DPI changes.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DIALOG_CONTROL_DPI_CHANGE_BEHAVIORS.DCDC_DISABLE_FONT_UPDATE
member.summary: Prevents the dialog manager from sending an updated font to the child window via WM_SETFONT in response to a DPI change.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DIALOG_CONTROL_DPI_CHANGE_BEHAVIORS.DCDC_DISABLE_RELAYOUT
member.summary: Prevents the dialog manager from resizing and repositioning the child window in response to a DPI change.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.DIALOG_DPI_CHANGE_BEHAVIORS
member.summary: In Per Monitor v2 contexts, dialogs will automatically respond to DPI changes by resizing themselves and re-computing the positions of their child windows (here referred to as re-layouting). This enum works in conjunction with SetDialogDpiChangeBehavior in order to override the default DPI scaling behavior for dialogs. This does not affect DPI scaling behavior for the child windows of dialogs(beyond re-layouting), which is controlled by .

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DIALOG_DPI_CHANGE_BEHAVIORS.DDC_DEFAULT
member.summary: The default behavior of the dialog manager. In response to a DPI change, the dialog manager will re-layout each control, update the font on each control, resize the dialog, and update the dialog's own font.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DIALOG_DPI_CHANGE_BEHAVIORS.DDC_DISABLE_ALL
member.summary: Prevents the dialog manager from responding to and , disabling all default DPI scaling behavior.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DIALOG_DPI_CHANGE_BEHAVIORS.DDC_DISABLE_RESIZE
member.summary: Prevents the dialog manager from resizing the dialog in response to a DPI change.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DIALOG_DPI_CHANGE_BEHAVIORS.DDC_DISABLE_CONTROL_RELAYOUT
member.summary: Prevents the dialog manager from re-layouting all of the dialogue's immediate children HWNDs in response to a DPI change.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGITEMTEMPLATE.style
member.summary: The style of the control. This member can be a combination of window style values (such as WS_BORDER) and one or more of the control style values (such as BS_PUSHBUTTON and ES_LEFT).

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGITEMTEMPLATE.dwExtendedStyle
member.summary: The extended styles for a window. This member is not used to create controls in dialog boxes, but applications that use dialog box templates can use it to create other types of windows.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGITEMTEMPLATE.x
member.summary: The x-coordinate, in dialog box units, of the upper-left corner of the control. This coordinate is always relative to the upper-left corner of the dialog box's client area.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGITEMTEMPLATE.y
member.summary: The y-coordinate, in dialog box units, of the upper-left corner of the control. This coordinate is always relative to the upper-left corner of the dialog box's client area.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGITEMTEMPLATE.cx
member.summary: The width, in dialog box units, of the control.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGITEMTEMPLATE.cy
member.summary: The height, in dialog box units, of the control.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGITEMTEMPLATE.id
member.summary: The control identifier.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.DLGTEMPLATE
member.summary: Defines the dimensions and style of a dialog box. This structure, always the first in a standard template for a dialog box, also specifies the number of controls in the dialog box and therefore specifies the number of subsequent structures in the template.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGTEMPLATE.style
member.summary:
The style of the dialog box. This member can be a combination of window style values (such as WS_CAPTION and WS_SYSMENU) and dialog box style values (such as DS_CENTER).
If the style member includes the DS_SETFONT style, the header of the dialog box template contains additional data specifying the font to use for text in the client area and controls of the dialog box. The font data begins on the WORD boundary that follows the title array. The font data specifies a 16-bit point size value and a Unicode font name string. If possible, the system creates a font according to the specified values. Then the system sends a WM_SETFONT message to the dialog box and to each control to provide a handle to the font. If DS_SETFONT is not specified, the dialog box template does not include the font data.
The DS_SHELLFONT style is not supported in the DLGTEMPLATE header.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGTEMPLATE.dwExtendedStyle
member.summary: The extended styles for a window. This member is not used to create dialog boxes, but applications that use dialog box templates can use it to create other types of windows.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGTEMPLATE.cdit
member.summary: The number of items in the dialog box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGTEMPLATE.x
member.summary: The x-coordinate, in dialog box units, of the upper-left corner of the dialog box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGTEMPLATE.y
member.summary: The y-coordinate, in dialog box units, of the upper-left corner of the dialog box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGTEMPLATE.cx
member.summary: The width, in dialog box units, of the dialog box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DLGTEMPLATE.cy
member.summary: The height, in dialog box units, of the dialog box.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.DPI_AWARENESS
member.summary: Identifies the dots per inch (dpi) setting for a thread, process, or window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DPI_AWARENESS.DPI_AWARENESS_INVALID
member.summary: Invalid DPI awareness. This is an invalid DPI awareness value.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DPI_AWARENESS.DPI_AWARENESS_UNAWARE
member.summary: DPI unaware. This process does not scale for DPI changes and is always assumed to have a scale factor of 100% (96 DPI). It will be automatically scaled by the system on any other DPI setting.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DPI_AWARENESS.DPI_AWARENESS_SYSTEM_AWARE
member.summary: System DPI aware. This process does not scale for DPI changes. It will query for the DPI once and use that value for the lifetime of the process. If the DPI changes, the process will not adjust to the new DPI value. It will be automatically scaled up or down by the system when the DPI changes from the system value.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DPI_AWARENESS.DPI_AWARENESS_PER_MONITOR_AWARE
member.summary: Per monitor DPI aware. This process checks for the DPI when it is created and adjusts the scale factor whenever the DPI changes. These processes are not automatically scaled by the system.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.DPI_HOSTING_BEHAVIOR
member.summary: Identifies the DPI hosting behavior for a window. This behavior allows windows created in the thread to host child windows with a different DPI_AWARENESS_CONTEXT.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DPI_HOSTING_BEHAVIOR.DPI_HOSTING_BEHAVIOR_INVALID
member.summary: Invalid DPI hosting behavior. This usually occurs if the previous call used an invalid parameter.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DPI_HOSTING_BEHAVIOR.DPI_HOSTING_BEHAVIOR_DEFAULT
member.summary: Default DPI hosting behavior. The associated window behaves as normal, and cannot create or re-parent child windows with a different DPI_AWARENESS_CONTEXT.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.DPI_HOSTING_BEHAVIOR.DPI_HOSTING_BEHAVIOR_MIXED
member.summary: Mixed DPI hosting behavior. This enables the creation and re-parenting of child windows with different DPI_AWARENESS_CONTEXT. These child windows will be independently scaled by the OS.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.GetMenuDefaultItemFlags
member.summary: Flags to be passed into the method.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.GetMenuDefaultItemFlags.GMDI_USEDISABLED
member.summary: The function is to return a default item, even if it is disabled. By default, the function skips disabled or grayed items.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.GetMenuDefaultItemFlags.GMDI_GOINTOPOPUPS
member.summary: If the default item is one that opens a submenu, the function is to search recursively in the corresponding submenu. If the submenu has no default item, the return value identifies the item that opens the submenu. By default, the function returns the first default item on the specified menu, regardless of whether it is an item that opens a submenu.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.GetWindowCommands
member.summary: The commands that can be used as arguments to .

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.GetWindowCommands.GW_HWNDFIRST
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the window of the same type that is highest in the Z order. If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies a topmost window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies a top-level window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies a sibling window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.GetWindowCommands.GW_HWNDLAST
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the window of the same type that is lowest in the Z order. If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies a topmost window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies a top-level window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies a sibling window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.GetWindowCommands.GW_HWNDNEXT
member.summary: Returns a handle to the window below the given window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.GetWindowCommands.GW_HWNDPREV
member.summary: Returns a handle to the window above the given window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.GetWindowCommands.GW_OWNER
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the specified window's owner window, if any. For more information, see Owned Windows.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.GetWindowCommands.GW_CHILD
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the child window at the top of the Z order, if the specified window is a parent window; otherwise, the retrieved handle is NULL. The function examines only child windows of the specified window. It does not examine descendant windows.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.GetWindowCommands.GW_ENABLEDPOPUP
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the enabled popup window owned by the specified window (the search uses the first such window found using ); otherwise, if there are no enabled popup windows, the retrieved handle is that of the specified window.

member.summary: Used by to store information for synthesizing input events such as keystrokes, mouse movement, and mouse clicks.

member.summary: The type of the input event.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.INPUT.Inputs
member.summary: The union of mouse, keyboard and hardware input.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.INPUT.InputUnion
member.summary: Describes some kind of input.
member.remarks: This struct is a union where all fields share memory address space.
member.devremarks: From http://www.pinvoke.net/default.aspx/Structures/INPUT.html: The last 3 fields are a union, which is why they are all at the same memory offset. On 64-Bit systems, the offset of the , and fields is 8, because the nested struct uses the alignment of its biggest member, which is 8 (due to the 64-bit pointer in ). By separating the union into its own structure, rather than placing the , and fields directly in the INPUT structure, we assure that the .NET structure will have the correct alignment on both 32 and 64 bit.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.KEYEVENTF.KEYEVENTF_KEYUP

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.LoadImageFlags
member.summary: Represents various image types.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.LoadImageFlags.LR_CREATEDIBSECTION
member.summary: When the uType parameter specifies , causes the function to return a DIB section bitmap rather than a compatible bitmap. This flag is useful for loading a bitmap without mapping it to the colors of the display device.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.LoadImageFlags.LR_DEFAULTCOLOR
member.summary: The default flag; it does nothing. All it means is "not ".

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.LoadImageFlags.LR_DEFAULTSIZE
member.summary: Uses the width or height specified by the system metric values for cursors or icons, if the cxDesired or cyDesired values are set to zero. If this flag is not specified and cxDesired and cyDesired are set to zero, the function uses the actual resource size. If the resource contains multiple images, the function uses the size of the first image.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.LoadImageFlags.LR_LOADFROMFILE
member.summary: Loads the stand-alone image from the file specified by lpszName (icon, cursor, or bitmap file).

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.LoadImageFlags.LR_LOADMAP3DCOLORS
member.summary:
Searches the color table for the image and replaces the following shades of gray with the corresponding 3-D color.
Dk Gray, RGB(128,128,128) with COLOR_3DSHADOW
Gray, RGB(192,192,192) with COLOR_3DFACE
Lt Gray, RGB(223,223,223) with COLOR_3DLIGHT
Do not use this option if you are loading a bitmap with a color depth greater than 8bpp.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.LoadImageFlags.LR_LOADTRANSPARENT
member.summary: Retrieves the color value of the first pixel in the image and replaces the corresponding entry in the color table with the default window color (COLOR_WINDOW). All pixels in the image that use that entry become the default window color. This value applies only to images that have corresponding color tables. Do not use this option if you are loading a bitmap with a color depth greater than 8bpp. If fuLoad includes both the and values, takes precedence. However, the color table entry is replaced with COLOR_3DFACE rather than COLOR_WINDOW.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.LoadImageFlags.LR_MONOCHROME
member.summary: Loads the image in black and white.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.LoadImageFlags.LR_SHARED
member.summary: Shares the image handle if the image is loaded multiple times. If is not set, a second call to LoadImage for the same resource will load the image again and return a different handle. When you use this flag, the system will destroy the resource when it is no longer needed. Do not use for images that have non-standard sizes, that may change after loading, or that are loaded from a file. When loading a system icon or cursor, you must use or the function will fail to load the resource. This function finds the first image in the cache with the requested resource name, regardless of the size requested.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.LoadImageFlags.LR_VGACOLOR
member.summary: Uses true VGA colors.

member.summary: Uses the default color format.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.LookupIconIdFromDirectoryExFlags.LR_MONOCHROME

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.MapVirtualKeyTranslation
member.summary: The translation to be performed in .

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MapVirtualKeyTranslation.MAPVK_VK_TO_CHAR
member.summary: uCode is a virtual-key code and is translated into an unshifted character value in the low-order word of the return value. Dead keys (diacritics) are indicated by setting the top bit of the return value. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MapVirtualKeyTranslation.MAPVK_VK_TO_VSC
member.summary: uCode is a virtual-key code and is translated into a scan code. If it is a virtual-key code that does not distinguish between left- and right-hand keys, the left-hand scan code is returned. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MapVirtualKeyTranslation.MAPVK_VSC_TO_VK
member.summary: uCode is a scan code and is translated into a virtual-key code that does not distinguish between left- and right-hand keys. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MapVirtualKeyTranslation.MAPVK_VSC_TO_VK_EX
member.summary: uCode is a scan code and is translated into a virtual-key code that distinguishes between left- and right-hand keys. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuInfoStyle.MNS_AUTODISMISS
member.summary: Menu automatically ends when mouse is outside the menu for approximately 10 seconds.

member.summary: The same space is reserved for the check mark and the bitmap. If the check mark is drawn, the bitmap is not. All checkmarks and bitmaps are aligned. Used for menus where some items use checkmarks and some use bitmaps.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuInfoStyle.MNS_DRAGDROP
member.summary: Menu items are OLE drop targets or drag sources. Menu owner receives and messages.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuInfoStyle.MNS_MODELESS
member.summary: Menu is modeless; that is, there is no menu modal message loop while the menu is active.

member.summary: No space is reserved to the left of an item for a check mark. The item can still be selected, but the check mark will not appear next to the item.

member.summary: Menu owner receives a message instead of a message when the user makes a selection. is a menu header style and has no effect when applied to individual sub menus.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags
member.summary: Controls the appearance and behavior of a menu item.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_BITMAP
member.summary: Uses a bitmap as the menu item. The lpNewItem parameter contains a handle to the bitmap.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_CHECKED
member.summary: Places a check mark next to the menu item. If the application provides check-mark bitmaps (see SetMenuItemBitmaps) this flag displays the check-mark bitmap next to the menu item.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_DISABLED
member.summary: Disables the menu item so that it cannot be selected, but the flag does not gray it.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_ENABLED
member.summary: Enables the menu item so that it can be selected, and restores it from its grayed state.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_GRAYED
member.summary: Disables the menu item and grays it so that it cannot be selected.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_MENUBARBREAK
member.summary: Functions the same as the MF_MENUBREAK flag for a menu bar. For a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu, the new column is separated from the old column by a vertical line.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_MENUBREAK
member.summary: Places the item on a new line (for a menu bar) or in a new column (for a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu) without separating columns.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_OWNERDRAW
member.summary: Specifies that the item is an owner-drawn item. Before the menu is displayed for the first time, the window that owns the menu receives a WM_MEASUREITEM message to retrieve the width and height of the menu item. The WM_DRAWITEM message is then sent to the window procedure of the owner window whenever the appearance of the menu item must be updated.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_POPUP
member.summary: Specifies that the menu item opens a drop-down menu or submenu. The uIDNewItem parameter specifies a handle to the drop-down menu or submenu. This flag is used to add a menu name to a menu bar, or a menu item that opens a submenu to a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_SEPARATOR
member.summary: Draws a horizontal dividing line. This flag is used only in a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu. The line cannot be grayed, disabled, or highlighted. The lpNewItem and uIDNewItem parameters are ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_STRING
member.summary: Specifies that the menu item is a text string; the lpNewItem parameter is a pointer to the string.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_UNCHECKED
member.summary: Does not place a check mark next to the item (default). If the application supplies check-mark bitmaps (see SetMenuItemBitmaps), this flag displays the clear bitmap next to the menu item.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_BYCOMMAND
member.summary: Indicates that the menu item is identified by its command.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_BYPOSITION
member.summary: Indicates that the menu item is identified by its zero-based relative position.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_UNHILITE
member.summary: Removes highlighting from the menu item.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_HILITE
member.summary: Highlights the menu item

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemFlags.MF_END
member.summary: Obsolete -- only used by old RES files

member.summary: An application-defined value associated with the menu item. Set to to use .

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MENUITEMINFO.dwTypeData
member.summary:
The contents of the menu item. The meaning of this member depends on the value of fType and is used only if the MIIM_TYPE flag is set in the fMask member.
To retrieve a menu item of type , first find the size of the string by setting the member of to and then calling . The value of +1 is the size needed. Then allocate a buffer of this size, place the pointer to the buffer in dwTypeData, increment cch, and call once again to fill the buffer with the string. If the retrieved menu item is of some other type, then sets the member to a value whose type is specified by the member.
When using with the function, this member should contain a value whose type is specified by the member.
dwTypeData is used only if the flag is set in the member.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MENUITEMINFO.cch
member.summary:
The length of the menu item text, in characters, when information is received about a menu item of the
type. However, is used only if the flag is set in the member and is zero otherwise. Also, is ignored when the content of a menu item is set by calling .
Note that, before calling , the application must set to the length of the buffer pointed to by the member. If the retrieved menu item is of type (as indicated by the member), then changes to the length of the menu item text. If the retrieved menu item is of some other type, sets the field to zero.
The member is used when the flag is set in the member.

Displays the menu item using a bitmap. The low-order word of the member is the bitmap handle, and the member is ignored.
is replaced by and .

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemType.MFT_MENUBARBREAK
member.summary: Places the menu item on a new line (for a menu bar) or in a new column (for a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu). For a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu, a vertical line separates the new column from the old.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemType.MFT_MENUBREAK
member.summary: Places the menu item on a new line (for a menu bar) or in a new column (for a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu). For a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu, the columns are not separated by a vertical line.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemType.MFT_OWNERDRAW
member.summary: Assigns responsibility for drawing the menu item to the window that owns the menu. The window receives a WM_MEASUREITEM message before the menu is displayed for the first time, and a WM_DRAWITEM message whenever the appearance of the menu item must be updated. If this value is specified, the dwTypeData member contains an application-defined value.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemType.MFT_RADIOCHECK
member.summary: Displays selected menu items using a radio-button mark instead of a check mark if the member is .

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemType.MFT_RIGHTJUSTIFY
member.summary: Right-justifies the menu item and any subsequent items. This value is valid only if the menu item is in a menu bar.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemType.MFT_RIGHTORDER
member.summary: Specifies that menus cascade right-to-left (the default is left-to-right). This is used to support right-to-left languages, such as Arabic and Hebrew.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MenuItemType.MFT_SEPARATOR
member.summary: Specifies that the menu item is a separator. A menu item separator appears as a horizontal dividing line. The dwTypeData and cch members are ignored. This value is valid only in a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions
member.summary: Flags that define appearance and behavior of a standard message box displayed by a call to the function.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_OK
member.summary: The message box contains one push button: OK. This is the default.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_OKCANCEL
member.summary: The message box contains two push buttons: OK and Cancel.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_ABORTRETRYIGNORE
member.summary: The message box contains three push buttons: Abort, Retry, and Ignore.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_YESNOCANCEL
member.summary: The message box contains three push buttons: Yes, No, and Cancel.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_YESNO
member.summary: The message box contains two push buttons: Yes and No.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_RETRYCANCEL
member.summary: The message box contains two push buttons: Retry and Cancel.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_CANCELTRYCONTINUE
member.summary: The message box contains three push buttons: Cancel, Try Again, Continue. Use this message box type instead of .

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_ICONSTOP
member.summary: A stop-sign icon appears in the message box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_ICONERROR
member.summary: A stop-sign icon appears in the message box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_ICONHAND
member.summary: A stop-sign icon appears in the message box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_ICONQUESTION
member.summary: A question-mark icon appears in the message box. The question-mark message icon is no longer recommended because it does not clearly represent a specific type of message and because the phrasing of a message as a question could apply to any message type. In addition, users can confuse the message symbol question mark with Help information. Therefore, do not use this question mark message symbol in your message boxes. The system continues to support its inclusion only for backward compatibility.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_ICONWARNING
member.summary: An exclamation-point icon appears in the message box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_ICONEXCLAMATION
member.summary: An exclamation-point icon appears in the message box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_ICONASTERISK
member.summary: An icon consisting of a lowercase letter i in a circle appears in the message box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_ICONINFORMATION
member.summary: An icon consisting of a lowercase letter i in a circle appears in the message box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_USERICON
member.summary: Uses an user defined icon

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_DEFBUTTON1
member.summary: The first button is the default button. MB_DEFBUTTON1 is the default unless , , or is specified.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_DEFBUTTON2
member.summary: The second button is the default button.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_DEFBUTTON3
member.summary: The third button is the default button.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_DEFBUTTON4
member.summary: The fourth button is the default button.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_APPLMODAL
member.summary: The user must respond to the message box before continuing work in the window identified by the hWnd parameter. However, the user can move to the windows of other threads and work in those windows. Depending on the hierarchy of windows in the application, the user may be able to move to other windows within the thread. All child windows of the parent of the message box are automatically disabled, but pop-up windows are not. MB_APPLMODAL is the default if neither nor is specified.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_SYSTEMMODAL
member.summary: Same as except that the message box has the WS_EX_TOPMOST style. Use system-modal message boxes to notify the user of serious, potentially damaging errors that require immediate attention (for example, running out of memory). This flag has no effect on the user's ability to interact with windows other than those associated with hWnd.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_TASKMODAL
member.summary: Same as except that all the top-level windows belonging to the current thread are disabled if the hWnd parameter is NULL. Use this flag when the calling application or library does not have a window handle available but still needs to prevent input to other windows in the calling thread without suspending other threads.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_HELP
member.summary: Adds a Help button to the message box. When the user clicks the Help button or presses F1, the system sends a message to the owner.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_NOFOCUS
member.summary: Undocumented

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_SETFOREGROUND
member.summary: The message box becomes the foreground window. Internally, the system calls the function for the message box.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_DEFAULT_DESKTOP_ONLY
member.summary: Same as desktop of the interactive window station. For more information, see Window Stations. If the current input desktop is not the default desktop, MessageBox does not return until the user switches to the default desktop.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_TOPMOST
member.summary: The message box is created with the WS_EX_TOPMOST window style.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_RIGHT
member.summary: The text is right-justified.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_RTLREADING
member.summary: Displays message and caption text using right-to-left reading order on Hebrew and Arabic systems.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MessageBoxOptions.MB_SERVICE_NOTIFICATION
member.summary: The caller is a service notifying the user of an event. The function displays a message box on the current active desktop, even if there is no user logged on to the computer. If this flag is set, the hWnd parameter must be NULL. This is so that the message box can appear on a desktop other than the desktop corresponding to the hWnd.
member.remarks: Terminal Services: If the calling thread has an impersonation token, the function directs the message box to the session specified in the impersonation token.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFO
member.summary: The structure contains information about a display monitor. The function stores information in a structure or a structure. The structure is a subset of the structure. The structure adds a string member to contain a name for the display monitor.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFO.cbSize
member.summary: The size of the structure, in bytes. Set this member to sizeof(MONITORINFO) before calling the function. Doing so lets the function determine the type of structure you are passing to it.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFO.rcMonitor
member.summary: A structure that specifies the display monitor rectangle, expressed in virtual-screen coordinates. Note that if the monitor is not the primary display monitor, some of the rectangle's coordinates may be negative values.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFO.rcWork
member.summary: A structure that specifies the work area rectangle of the display monitor, expressed in virtual-screen coordinates. Note that if the monitor is not the primary display monitor, some of the rectangle's coordinates may be negative values.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFO.dwFlags
member.summary: A set of flags that represent attributes of the display monitor.

member.name: M:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFO.Create
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct with the field initialized.
member.returns: The newly initialized struct.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFOEX
member.summary: The structure contains information about a display monitor. The function stores information into a structure or a MONITORINFO structure. The structure is a superset of the MONITORINFO structure. The structure adds a string member to contain a name for the display monitor.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFOEX.cbSize
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the structure. Set this member to sizeof(MONITORINFOEX) (72) before calling the function. Doing so lets the function determine the type of structure you are passing to it.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFOEX.Monitor
member.summary: A structure that specifies the display monitor rectangle, expressed in virtual-screen coordinates. Note that if the monitor is not the primary display monitor, some of the rectangle's coordinates may be negative values.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFOEX.WorkArea
member.summary: A structure that specifies the work area rectangle of the display monitor that can be used by applications, expressed in virtual-screen coordinates. Windows uses this rectangle to maximize an application on the monitor. The rest of the area in rcMonitor contains system windows such as the task bar and side bars. Note that if the monitor is not the primary display monitor, some of the rectangle's coordinates may be negative values.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFOEX.Flags
member.summary: The attributes of the display monitor.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFOEX.DeviceName
member.summary: A string that specifies the device name of the monitor being used. Most applications have no use for a display monitor name, and so can save some bytes by using a MONITORINFO structure.

member.name: M:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFOEX.Create
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct with the field initialized.
member.returns: The newly initialized struct.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFO_Flags
member.summary: Flags that may be defined on the field.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFO_Flags.None
member.summary: No flags.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MONITORINFO_Flags.MONITORINFOF_PRIMARY
member.summary: This is the primary display monitor.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.MOUSEEVENTF
member.summary: A set of bit flags that specify various aspects of mouse motion and button clicks. The bits in this member can be any reasonable combination of the following values.
member.remarks: The bit flags that specify mouse button status are set to indicate changes in status, not ongoing conditions. For example, if the left mouse button is pressed and held down, MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTDOWN is set when the left button is first pressed, but not for subsequent motions. Similarly, MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTUP is set only when the button is first released. You cannot specify both the MOUSEEVENTF_WHEEL flag and either MOUSEEVENTF_XDOWN or MOUSEEVENTF_XUP flags simultaneously in the parameter, because they both require use of the field.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.MOUSEINPUT
member.summary: Contains information about a simulated mouse event.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MOUSEINPUT.dx
member.summary: The absolute position of the mouse, or the amount of motion since the last mouse event was generated, depending on the value of the dwFlags member. Absolute data is specified as the x coordinate of the mouse; relative data is specified as the number of pixels moved.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MOUSEINPUT.dy
member.summary: The absolute position of the mouse, or the amount of motion since the last mouse event was generated, depending on the value of the dwFlags member. Absolute data is specified as the y coordinate of the mouse; relative data is specified as the number of pixels moved.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MOUSEINPUT.mouseData
member.summary: If dwFlags contains , then specifies the amount of wheel movement. A positive value indicates that the wheel was rotated forward, away from the user; a negative value indicates that the wheel was rotated backward, toward the user. One wheel click is defined as , which is 120. If dwFlags does not contain , , or , then mouseData should be zero. If dwFlags contains or , then mouseData specifies which X buttons were pressed or released.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MOUSEINPUT.dwFlags
member.summary: A set of bit flags that specify various aspects of mouse motion and button clicks. The bits in this member can be any reasonable combination of the following values. See MSDN docs for more info.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MOUSEINPUT.time
member.summary: The time stamp for the event, in milliseconds. If this parameter is 0, the system will provide its own time stamp.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MOUSEINPUT.dwExtraInfo
member.summary: An additional value associated with the mouse event. An application calls GetMessageExtraInfo to obtain this extra information.

member.name: P:PInvoke.User32.MOUSEINPUT.dwExtraInfo_IntPtr
member.summary: An additional value associated with the mouse event. An application calls GetMessageExtraInfo to obtain this extra information.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags
member.summary: Controls various aspects of mouse motion and button clicking.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_ABSOLUTE
member.summary: The dx and dy parameters contain normalized absolute coordinates. If not set, those parameters contain relative data: the change in position since the last reported position. This flag can be set, or not set, regardless of what kind of mouse or mouse-like device, if any, is connected to the system. For further information about relative mouse motion, see the following Remarks section.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTDOWN
member.summary: The left button is down.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTUP
member.summary: The left button is up.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_MIDDLEDOWN
member.summary: The middle button is down.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_MIDDLEUP
member.summary: The middle button is up.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_MOVE
member.summary: Movement occurred.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_RIGHTDOWN
member.summary: The right button is down.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_RIGHTUP
member.summary: The right button is up.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_WHEEL
member.summary: The wheel has been moved, if the mouse has a wheel. The amount of movement is specified in dwData

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_XDOWN
member.summary: An X button was pressed.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_XUP
member.summary: An X button was released.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.mouse_eventFlags.MOUSEEVENTF_HWHEEL
member.summary: The wheel button is tilted.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsExFlags
member.summary: Flags for the method.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsExFlags.None
member.summary: The function returns when any one of the objects is signaled. The return value indicates the object whose state caused the function to return.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsExFlags.MWMO_WAITALL
member.summary: The function returns when all objects in the pHandles array are signaled and an input event has been received, all at the same time.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsExFlags.MWMO_ALERTABLE
member.summary: The function also returns if an APC has been queued to the thread with QueueUserAPC while the thread is in the waiting state.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsExFlags.MWMO_INPUTAVAILABLE
member.summary: The function returns if input exists for the queue, even if the input has been seen (but not removed) using a call to another function, such as .

member.summary: The handle flags. The pvInfo parameter must point to a structure.

member.summary: The name of the object, as a string.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ObjectInformationType.UOI_TYPE
member.summary: The type name of the object, as a string

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ObjectInformationType.UOI_USER_SID
member.summary: The SID structure that identifies the user that is currently associated with the specified object. If no user is associated with the object, the value returned in the buffer pointed to by lpnLengthNeeded is zero. Note that SID is a variable length structure. You will usually make a call to GetUserObjectInformation to determine the length of the SID before retrieving its value.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ObjectInformationType.UOI_HEAPSIZE
member.summary: The size of the desktop heap, in KB, as a ULONG value. The hObj parameter must be a handle to a desktop object, otherwise, the function fails.
member.remarks: Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.ObjectInformationType.UOI_IO
member.summary: TRUE if the hObj parameter is a handle to the desktop object that is receiving input from the user. FALSE otherwise.
member.remarks: Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.ScanCode
member.summary: General keyboard scan code constants on the same order that it can be found on constants.
member.remarks: Scan codes are device-dependant values, these are general values used by most keyboards.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.SendMessageTimeoutFlags
member.summary: Possible flag values for .

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SendMessageTimeoutFlags.SMTO_ABORTIFHUNG
member.summary: The function returns without waiting for the time-out period to elapse if the receiving thread appears to not respond or "hangs."

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SendMessageTimeoutFlags.SMTO_BLOCK
member.summary: Prevents the calling thread from processing any other requests until the function returns.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SendMessageTimeoutFlags.SMTO_NORMAL
member.summary: The calling thread is not prevented from processing other requests while waiting for the function to return.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SendMessageTimeoutFlags.SMTO_NOTIMEOUTIFNOTHUNG
member.summary: The function does not enforce the time-out period as long as the receiving thread is processing messages.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SendMessageTimeoutFlags.SMTO_ERRORONEXIT
member.summary: The function should return 0 if the receiving window is destroyed or its owning thread dies while the message is being processed.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_ASYNCWINDOWPOS
member.summary: If the calling thread and the thread that owns the window are attached to different input queues, the system posts the request to the thread that owns the window. This prevents the calling thread from blocking its execution while other threads process the request.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_DEFERERASE
member.summary: Prevents generation of the WM_SYNCPAINT message.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_DRAWFRAME
member.summary: Draws a frame (defined in the window's class description) around the window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_FRAMECHANGED
member.summary: Applies new frame styles set using the SetWindowLong function. Sends a WM_NCCALCSIZE message to the window, even if the window's size is not being changed. If this flag is not specified, WM_NCCALCSIZE is sent only when the window's size is being changed.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_HIDEWINDOW
member.summary: Hides the window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_NOACTIVATE
member.summary: Does not activate the window. If this flag is not set, the window is activated and moved to the top of either the topmost or non-topmost group (depending on the setting of the hWndInsertAfter parameter).

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_NOCOPYBITS
member.summary: Discards the entire contents of the client area. If this flag is not specified, the valid contents of the client area are saved and copied back into the client area after the window is sized or repositioned.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_NOMOVE
member.summary: Retains the current position (ignores X and Y parameters).

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_NOOWNERZORDER
member.summary: Does not change the owner window's position in the Z order.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_NOREDRAW
member.summary: Does not redraw changes. If this flag is set, no repainting of any kind occurs. This applies to the client area, the nonclient area (including the title bar and scroll bars), and any part of the parent window uncovered as a result of the window being moved. When this flag is set, the application must explicitly invalidate or redraw any parts of the window and parent window that need redrawing.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_NOREPOSITION
member.summary: Same as the SWP_NOOWNERZORDER flag.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_NOSENDCHANGING
member.summary: Prevents the window from receiving the WM_WINDOWPOSCHANGING message.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_NOSIZE
member.summary: Retains the current size (ignores the cx and cy parameters).

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_NOZORDER
member.summary: Retains the current Z order (ignores the hWndInsertAfter parameter).

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SetWindowPosFlags.SWP_SHOWWINDOW
member.summary: Displays the window.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.SpecialWindowHandles
member.summary: Special window handles.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SpecialWindowHandles.HWND_TOP
member.summary: Places the window at the top of the Z order.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SpecialWindowHandles.HWND_BOTTOM
member.summary: Places the window at the bottom of the Z order. If the hWnd parameter identifies a topmost window, the window loses its topmost status and is placed at the bottom of all other windows.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SpecialWindowHandles.HWND_TOPMOST
member.summary: Places the window above all non-topmost windows. The window maintains its topmost position even when it is deactivated.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SpecialWindowHandles.HWND_NOTOPMOST
member.summary: Places the window above all non-topmost windows (that is, behind all topmost windows). This flag has no effect if the window is already a non-topmost window.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands
member.summary: wParam options for .

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_CLOSE
member.summary: Closes the window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_CONTEXTHELP
member.summary: Changes the cursor to a question mark with a pointer. If the user then clicks a control in the dialog box, the control receives a WM_HELP message.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_DEFAULT
member.summary: Selects the default item; the user double-clicked the window menu.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_HOTKEY
member.summary: Activates the window associated with the application-specified hot key. The lParam parameter identifies the window to activate.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_HSCROLL
member.summary: Scrolls horizontally.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SCF_ISSECURE
member.summary: Indicates whether the screen saver is secure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_KEYMENU
member.summary: Retrieves the window menu as a result of a keystroke. For more information, see the Remarks section.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_MAXIMIZE
member.summary: Maximizes the window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_MINIMIZE
member.summary: Minimizes the window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_MONITORPOWER
member.summary: Sets the state of the display. This command supports devices that have power-saving features, such as a battery-powered personal computer. The lParam parameter can have the following values: -1 (the display is powering on) 1 (the display is going to low power) 2 (the display is being shut off)

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_MOUSEMENU
member.summary: Retrieves the window menu as a result of a mouse click.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_MOVE
member.summary: Moves the window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_NEXTWINDOW
member.summary: Moves to the next window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_PREVWINDOW
member.summary: Moves to the previous window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_RESTORE
member.summary: Restores the window to its normal position and size.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_SCREENSAVE
member.summary: Executes the screen saver application specified in the [boot] section of the System.ini file.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_SIZE
member.summary: Sizes the window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_TASKLIST
member.summary: Activates the Start menu.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SysCommands.SC_VSCROLL
member.summary: Scrolls vertically.

member.name: T:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric
member.summary: Flags used in the function.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_ARRANGE
member.summary: The flags that specify how the system arranged minimized windows. For more information, see the Remarks section in this topic.
member.remarks: The SM_ARRANGE setting specifies how the system arranges minimized windows, and consists of a starting position and a direction.The starting position can be one of the following values. Value Meaning ARW_BOTTOMLEFT Start at the lower-left corner of the screen.The default position. ARW_BOTTOMRIGHT Start at the lower-right corner of the screen.Equivalent to ARW_STARTRIGHT. ARW_TOPLEFT Start at the upper-left corner of the screen.Equivalent to ARW_STARTTOP. ARW_TOPRIGHT Start at the upper-right corner of the screen.Equivalent to ARW_STARTTOP | SRW_STARTRIGHT. The direction in which to arrange minimized windows can be one of the following values. Value Meaning ARW_DOWN Arrange vertically, top to bottom. ARW_HIDE Hide minimized windows by moving them off the visible area of the screen. ARW_LEFT Arrange horizontally, left to right. ARW_RIGHT Arrange horizontally, right to left. ARW_UP Arrange vertically, bottom to top.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CLEANBOOT
member.summary: The value that specifies how the system is started: 0 Normal boot 1 Fail-safe boot 2 Fail-safe with network boot A fail-safe boot (also called SafeBoot, Safe Mode, or Clean Boot) bypasses the user startup files.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CMONITORS
member.summary: The number of display monitors on a desktop. For more information, see the Remarks section in this topic.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CMOUSEBUTTONS
member.summary: The number of buttons on a mouse, or zero if no mouse is installed.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXBORDER
member.summary: The width of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the SM_CXEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXCURSOR
member.summary: The width of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CXFIXEDFRAME.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXDOUBLECLK
member.summary: The width of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. , The second click must occur within the rectangle that is defined by SM_CXDOUBLECLK and SM_CYDOUBLECLK for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click. The two clicks must also occur within a specified time. To set the width of the double-click rectangle, call SystemParametersInfo with SPI_SETDOUBLECLKWIDTH.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels on either side of a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from the left of the mouse-down point and added to the right of it.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXEDGE
member.summary: The width of a 3-D border, in pixels. This metric is the 3-D counterpart of SM_CXBORDER.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXFIXEDFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. SM_CXFIXEDFRAME is the height of the horizontal border, and SM_CYFIXEDFRAME is the width of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CXDLGFRAME.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXFOCUSBORDER
member.summary: The width of the left and right edges of the focus rectangle that the DrawFocusRectdraws. This value is in pixels. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CXSIZEFRAME.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen that is not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfo function with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXHSCROLL
member.summary: The width of the arrow bitmap on a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXHTHUMB
member.summary: The width of the thumb box in a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXICON
member.summary: The default width of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions that SM_CXICON and SM_CYICON specifies.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXICONSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size SM_CXICONSPACING by SM_CYICONSPACING when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CXICON.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXMAXIMIZED
member.summary: The default width, in pixels, of a maximized top-level window on the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXMAXTRACK
member.summary: The default maximum width of a window that has a caption and sizing borders, in pixels. This metric refers to the entire desktop. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size larger than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXMENUCHECK
member.summary: The width of the default menu check-mark bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXMENUSIZE
member.summary: The width of menu bar buttons, such as the child window close button that is used in the multiple document interface, in pixels.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXMIN
member.summary: The minimum width of a window, in pixels.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXMINIMIZED
member.summary: The width of a minimized window, in pixels.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXMINSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for a minimized window, in pixels. Each minimized window fits into a rectangle this size when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CXMINIMIZED.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXMINTRACK
member.summary: The minimum tracking width of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXPADDEDBORDER
member.summary: The amount of border padding for captioned windows, in pixels. Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same value obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, HORZRES).

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXSIZE
member.summary: The width of a button in a window caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXSIZEFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the sizing border around the perimeter of a window that can be resized, in pixels. SM_CXSIZEFRAME is the width of the horizontal border, and SM_CYSIZEFRAME is the height of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CXFRAME.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXSMICON
member.summary: The recommended width of a small icon, in pixels. Small icons typically appear in window captions and in small icon view.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXSMSIZE
member.summary: The width of small caption buttons, in pixels.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the virtual screen, in pixels. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_XVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the coordinates for the left side of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CXVSCROLL
member.summary: The width of a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYBORDER
member.summary: The height of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the SM_CYEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYCAPTION
member.summary: The height of a caption area, in pixels.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYCURSOR
member.summary: The height of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CYFIXEDFRAME.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYDOUBLECLK
member.summary: The height of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. The second click must occur within the rectangle defined by SM_CXDOUBLECLK and SM_CYDOUBLECLK for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click. The two clicks must also occur within a specified time. To set the height of the double-click rectangle, call SystemParametersInfo with SPI_SETDOUBLECLKHEIGHT.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels above and below a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from above the mouse-down point and added below it.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYEDGE
member.summary: The height of a 3-D border, in pixels. This is the 3-D counterpart of SM_CYBORDER.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYFIXEDFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. SM_CXFIXEDFRAME is the height of the horizontal border, and SM_CYFIXEDFRAME is the width of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CYDLGFRAME.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYFOCUSBORDER
member.summary: The height of the top and bottom edges of the focus rectangle drawn byDrawFocusRect. This value is in pixels. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CYSIZEFRAME.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfo function with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYHSCROLL
member.summary: The height of a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYICON
member.summary: The default height of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions SM_CXICON and SM_CYICON.

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYSIZE

member.name: F:PInvoke.User32.SystemMetric.SM_CYSIZEFRAME
